00041    {

00171    private:
00172   
00174       DArray<Atom*>  atom1Ptrs_;  
00175 
00177       DArray<Atom*>  atom2Ptrs_;  
00178 
00180       DArray<int>    first_; 
00181 
00183       double cutoff_;
00184    
00186       int    atomCapacity_;     
00187    
00189       int    pairCapacity_;     
00190    
00192       int    nAtom1_;      
00193 
00195       int    nAtom2_; 
00196    
00198       int    maxNAtomLocal_;     
00199    
00201       int    maxNPairLocal_;     
00202    
00204       int    maxNAtom_;     
00205    
00207       int    maxNPair_;     
00208    
00210       int    buildCounter_;
00211 
00213       bool   isAllocated_;
00214   
00215       /* 
00216       * Implementation Notes:
00217       *
00218       * The pair list is stored in Atom* pointer arrays atom1Ptrs_, atom2Ptrs_, 
00219       * and in an integer array first_. Each element of atom1Ptrs_ contains a 
00220       * pointer to the first atom in a pair (the primary Atom). Each element 
00221       * of atom2Ptrs_ contains a pointer to the second atom in a pair (the 
00222       * secondary Atom).  Secondary atoms that are neighbors of the same 
00223       * primary atom are listed consecutively.  Element first_[i] contains the 
00224       * array index of the first element in atom2Ptrs_ that contains a neighbor 
00225       * of primary atom atom1Ptrs_[i]. Pointers to neighbors of primary atom
00226       * *atom1Ptrs_[i] are thus stored in elements first_[i] <= j < first_[i+1]
00227       * of atom2Ptrs_.  Each pair is included only once.
00228       *
00229       * The only way legal way to loop over all atom pairs, using the public 
00230       * interface of a PairList, is to use a PairListIterator. See the 
00231       * documentation of PairListIterator for a discussion of its usage. The 
00232       * resulting loop over pairs is equivalent to the following double loop 
00233       * over private member variables of PairList:
00234       * 
00235       *    int i, j;
00236       *    Atom* atom1Ptr;
00237       *    Atom* atom2Ptr;
00238       *
00239       *    \\ Loop over primary Atoms
00240       *    for (i = 0; i < nAtom1_; ++i) {
00241       *       atom1Ptr = atom1Ptrs_[i];
00242       *
00243       *       // Loop over secondary atoms
00244       *       for (j = first_[i]; j < first_[i+1]; ++j) {
00245       *           atom2Ptr = atom2Ptrs_[j];
00246       *
00247       *           // ... Do something with Atoms *atom1Ptr and *atom2Ptr.
00248       *
00249       *       }
00250       *    }
00251       *
00252       * Note that DArray<int> first_ contains nAtom1_ + 1 elements. The first
00253       * element, element first_[0] is equal to 0, and the last element,
00254       * first_[nAtom1_], is always equal to nAtom2_, the total number of 
00255       * pairs.
00256       */
00257 
00258    }; 
00259 
00260    /*
00261    * Get the current number of primary atoms in the pairlist.
00262    */ 
00263    inline int PairList::nAtom() const
00264    { return nAtom1_; }
00265 
00266    /*
00267    * Get the current number of pairs.
00268    */ 
00269    inline int PairList::nPair() const
00270    { return nAtom2_; }
00271

00276    {  return pairCapacity_; }

00300    { return buildCounter_; }

00306    { return isAllocated_; }
